message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a pulmonary nodule that is dense and irregularly calcified raises suspicion for lung cancer, especially with a significant smoking history. The most appropriate next step would be to obtain previous chest radiographs for comparison to determine if the nodule is new or has been present for a long time. If the nodule is new, then a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest can help further evaluate the size and characteristics of the nodule. Sputum cytology and flexible bronchoscopy with biopsy may also be considered to obtain a tissue diagnosis.

Obtaining previous chest radiographs for comparison would be the most appropriate first step to determine if the nodule is new. If the nodule is new or has grown, a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest would be the next step to further evaluate the nodule.
